conversation.content: So I wanted to talk to you about the salary we discussed for this position.
[very quickly] Oh right, yeah, um, the salary thing. I mean, we're still kind of working through all the details on that actually, there's a lot of moving parts with the budget and everything.
[extremely happy] But you said forty-five thousand was definitely doable last week!

[smiling speaking] Well, I mean, that was more of a, you know, ballpark figure we were throwing around. Things have gotten a bit more complicated since then with, uh, some organizational changes happening.
What kind of organizational changes? This is the third time you've mentioned something vague.

It's just—look, there's been some restructuring in, um, how we allocate resources across departments. I don't have all the details myself yet, which is frustrating, I know, but that's kind of where we're at.
Can you at least tell me if we're still in the same range?
Honestly? I wish I could give you a straight answer but, erm, everything's kind of up in the air right now. Maybe we could revisit this in a couple weeks when things settle down?
[laugh hysterically] A couple weeks? I already gave notice at my current job!
Oh. Oh no, that's—I didn't realize you'd already... Look, maybe I can, uh, talk to someone higher up and see if we can expedite things a bit.
Who exactly makes these decisions? Because you seemed pretty confident before.
Yeah, I mean, technically it goes through several layers of approval, and, well, sometimes what seems straightforward initially gets more complex when legal and HR get involved, you know?
[long pause] Are you trying to lowball me?
No, no, it's not like that at all. I just—there's been some, mmm, unexpected pushback from finance about new hire compensation packages across the board, not just yours.
[mocking] Unexpected pushback. Right. So what number are they actually comfortable with?
I don't... I don't actually have a firm number yet, which I realize sounds, uh, incredibly unprofessional. They're reviewing comparable positions in the market or something like that.
[happy] Well good news, I already did that research. Want to see my spreadsheet?

Oh, um, sure, but I should probably mention that they tend to have their own, err, methodology for these things. External research doesn't always align with how they view internal equity and all that.
So basically you're saying my research won't matter to them?
[enunciating every word] I'm saying that the process is more complicated than I initially led you to believe, and for that I genuinely apologize, because this isn't how this should have gone.
